She will remain forever exactly as she was on stage, dressed as an Egyptian queen, her words precisely scripted by William Shakespeare. It is the purest love you can imagine, a literary love affair, based on highly metaphorical language. Cleopatra was in love with Anthony, but for at least that one evening Bloom was Anthony,&nbspeven though he generally thinks of himself as more of a Falstaff, a hedonistic lover of life and adventurer.Harold is not in great shape. He can’t go very far, physically speaking, except for regular trips to the hospital and a rehab clinic. He is wheelchair-bound. His wife says it’s all down to a weak heart and arthritis. He has a nurse attending him while I’m there. He calls out for ice to be put on his back. His hand is trembling as he signs a copy of his book. The last time he wrote to me, he said, with an apocalyptic air, “my future is indeterminate”. Which applies to us all, but especially to Harold.&nbspSuzman in regal headdress as Cleopatra back in 1974 (ITVRex)His word for himself is “decrepit”. His mind is as sharp as ever it was, but inside a body that is in terminal decline. He is suffering from the opposite of dementia: decorporia, or physical disintegration. Mens sana in a corpore that is anything but sano. “There is a tremor in my fingers,” he writes, “my legs tend to give out, my teeth diminish, incipient macular degeneration dims my eyes, deafness increases, birdsong is scarcely heard, every height augments my apprehension of falling.” When he thinks about death, he quotes Dr Johnson: “This secret horrour of the last is inseparable from a thinking being whose life is limited, and to whom death is dreadful.”The Shakespeare cult shoves aside better writers in UK schoolsAll is True review: A fanciful but nuanced portrait of ShakespeareThere is a strange bond between us. My father’s name is also Harold. Middle name “Horatio”, which Bloom in his Shakespearean way is particularly fond of. “I’m old enough to be your father,” he says. I’m a bit of a prodigal symbolic son though. I struggle to remember the books my own father was particularly keen on. “He was more into motorbikes than books, to be honest,” I say.I can do the things that Harold can no longer do: hiking up the mountains of Montana or surfing.&nbsp“Don’t you ever get tired?” he says. In fact he hates going to the beach anyway: “I turn into a lobster when exposed to the sun.” He is content to keep on reading and keep on remembering.There is an implicit and explicit shoutout in his work to Proust’s In Search of Lost Time, merging memory and art with an evanescent impression of immortality. His earliest memory is of playing on the floor of his mother’s kitchen while she prepared the Sabbath meal. As she goes by he reaches out and touches her toes she reaches down and rumples his hair and says, “My sweet Harry”.Now, approaching the end of his story, he likes to quote the Book of Ecclesiastes, chapter 12: “Also when they shall be afraid of that which is high, and fears shall be in the way, and the almond tree shall flourish, and the grasshopper shall be a burden, and desire shall fail: because man goeth to his long home, and the mourners go about the street.” A line in Ecclesiastes which I’ve never heard him quote is this one: “Much study is a weariness of the flesh.” He adheres to the later Jewish tradition (perhaps imported via neoplatonism) of study being the path to salvation.He was born in 1930 in the Bronx, the son of immigrants, and grew up speaking Yiddish. “My father could speak Russian but refused to my mother spoke Polish, but refused to, for political reasons.” He only learned English around the age of six&nbspwhen his older sisters brought it home from school. So he came at it from the outside, rather like Joseph Conrad or Vladimir Nabokov, and was (and remains) bewitched by the language.Suzman&nbspon the Andrew Marr show in March&nbspthis year&nbspshow (Rex)His first reading was of the poets William Blake and Hart Crane, and he came to Shakespeare very early on, around the age of eight&nbspor nine&nbsphe thinks. “When I was very young, I read poems incessantly because I was lonely and somehow must have believed they could become people for me.” Legend has it that he could read a thousand pages an hour (he says it was only 400 at best).When I was very young, I read poems incessantly because I was lonely and somehow must have believed they could become people for meHe retains his youthful magical thinking about literature. Bloom has now written 40-something books about books – poetry, novels, plays, sacred texts. And his “memoir” is largely a homage to some of his favourite writers. As Oscar Wilde once said:&nbsp“Criticism is the only civilised form of autobiography.” Bloom harks back to the Bible often enough, but he is (as he describes Marcel Proust) more of “an atheistic mystic”. He quotes Ralph Waldo Emerson with approval: “As men’s prayers are a disease of their will, so are their creeds a disease of the intellect.Literature is the closest thing Harold has to a religion. Writers such as&nbspShakespeare and Milton and Wordsworth are like a substitute for the elusive Yahweh of the book of Genesis. Which explains why he retains an essentially sacred view of writing and is concerned to defend the “western canon” (from Homer through to James Joyce) against unbelievers and sceptics (which probably includes me).His attitude could be summed up in the opening lines of John’s Gospel: “In the beginning was the Word (logos), and the Word was with God (theon), and the Word was God.” But he was brought up on the Torah, the Jewish Bible, and was later seduced by the medieval tradition of Kabbalah, which says that the world was called into being via 10&nbsputterances (or “Sefirot”) and that therefore the whole of life is language. Organised religion, monotheism-style, derived from a reverence for the written text.Bloom derives consolation from the books that surround him on shelves and in piles on the table and on the floor. In Possessed by Memory, he writes that “Frequently at dawn, when I am very chilly and sit on the side of my bed, knowing it is not safe for me to go downstairs by myself in order to have some morning tea, I find deep peace in (Wallace) Stevens at his strongest.” If he was a Pharaoh, he would presumably ask to be buried with his books at his side.He met his wife Jeanne in New Haven in 1955. They were both students at Yale. She was doing a degree in history, he had just returned from a year on a Fulbright scholarship at Pembroke College, Cambridge (England). They married in 1958. Now, more than 60 years later, she says:&nbsp“You can’t stop him. Nothing would stop him from continuing to teach and write – it’s what he does.”How my article about young adult literature caused a ‘tweetstorm’Brexit isn’t a new idea, just ask DickensNobel Prize in Literature to be awarded twice this yearHe tends to remember people according to the books or poems they make him think of. So for example, there was a student called Fergy he met at Cornell. She was from Kentucky. “She had freckles and red hair, and I always told her that she looked like a female Huck Finn. Tall, slim, incredibly graceful, she had a way of running around me as we walked, since she was swift and I was slow.” Everything is mediated through literature. “Almost every night I dream about departed friends, sometimes mixing them up with fictive characters.”At this stage of the game – the dreaded “twilight” zone – Bloom has lost most of his old friends. His books are a way of calling them back again. The notion of a resurrection is still important to him – but one that precedes death. It is not surprising, when his own body is failing, if he finds consolation in images of transcendence, in which the soul is at last disembodied:Hence in a season of calm weatherHe quotes from Proust’s account of the death of (his imaginary writer) Bergotte: “They buried him, but all through that night of mourning, in the lighted shop-windows, his books, arranged three by three, kept vigil like angels with outspread wings and seemed, for him who was no more, the symbol of his resurrection”.There are perhaps three key concepts that recur again and again in Bloom: freedom, God, and immortality. All three of them appear as delusions, but ones that can be elusively attained or at least entertained in works of literature. Bloom would probably concur with Borges that literature is defined by “the sense of the imminence of a revelation that does not occur”.None of which stops Bloom from forever searching, not just for his own earliest memories but what might be something like the earliest memories of humanity, for what he calls, “a primal sound, cast out of our cosmos and wandering in exile through the interstellar spaces”. One of the stories he is most drawn to in the Old Testament – the Book of Genesis – is that of Jacob, who finds himself wrestling with a passing god all through the night. Bloom sees that – a close encounter with the ine – as an allegory of his own life.“In the half-light of my incessant nocturnal wakefulness, I begin to conceive of it as the struggle of every solitary deep reader to find in the highest literature what will suffice.”&nbspFrequently at dawn, when I am very chilly and sit on the side of my bed, knowing it is not safe for me to go downstairs by myself in order to have some morning tea, I find deep peace in (Wallace) Stevens at his strongestThe “most important thing in the book” he says is his theory of “self-other seeing”, notably in Shakespeare, where characters like Hamlet and Macbeth are capable of seeing themselves from the outside, as if they were someone else – an idea to some extent inspired or inflected by the experience he has had when (more than once) falling and breaking some fragile part of his body: “I recall the repetition of an acute phantasmagoria that this was not happening to me but to some other person.”One of his favourite words is agon, nothing to do with “agony” as such, but definitely concerned with struggle, as if in an arena (like Ben Hurr). He is certainly always struggling with something or someone, whether god or man, or just entropy in general.Finnegans Wake springs to mind.) Books are old school and contrive to hold new school technology at bay. “The final book here, The Book of Numbers, by the still-youthful Joshua Cohen, is a courageous assault on our Age of the Screen, the great grey ocean of the internet.”I quote that from Bright Book of Life: Fifty-Two Novels to Reread ‘Ere I Vanish. While I was hanging out chez Bloom, as well as emailing Dame Janet, I also had to email myself the manuscripts of two other books that Harold has already written but not yet published.Bright Book, the other is Take Arms Against a Sea of Troubles, a study of poetry, or “the power of the reader’s mind over a universe of death”. As his wife says, there is no stopping him. Each book is a way of deferring death, a bulwark against the erosion of time, a “symbol of his resurrection”.In all writers and all times, in philosophers and poets, Bloom finds consolation – companionship – in the face of the void. But if you had to name one, it would have to be Shakespeare, and precariously poised as he is between being and non-being, it would have to be in the figure of Hamlet: “We defy augury. There’s a special providence in the fall of a sparrow. If it be, ‘tis not to come if it be not to come, it will be now it if be not now, yet it will come. The readiness is all. Since no man, of aught he leaves, knows aught, what is’t to leave betimes? Let be.”Andy Martin is the author of With Child: Lee Child and the Readers of Jack Reacher (Polity) and teaches at the University of CambridgeOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsUnusual little lifeforms could live for yearsClick to followThe Independent TechThere may be life on the Moon.A spacecraft that crashed landed on the lunar surface have spilled tiny bugs across it, which may have&nbspseeded&nbspit with life.What's more, the new residents are tardigrades – considered the most resilient life form on Earth, they could be able to survive on the alien surface of the Moon.The visitors made their way to the Moon on board the Beresheet probe, which was designed to become the first private lander to successfully arrive on the surface. When it arrived in April, however, it crashed, and the mission was aborted.For most people and the majority of the mission, that catastrophic event brought everything to a close. But the tardigrades – true to their reputation for being hardy – might have survived the crashed and been spread across the surface, where they could be living on today.Created with Sketch.Best NASA pictures of the month - July 2019 Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A total solar eclipse as seen from the US National Science Federation observatory in the Chilean Andes on 2 JulyA composite image of the Cygnus OB2 star cluster composed of pictures taken by the Isaac Newton Telescope and Spitzer Space Telescope on July 24The spacecraft Soyuz MS-13 is launched at the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on July 20A copy of LIFE magazine from July 4 1969 signed by Michael Collins is seen onboard the Soyuz spacecraftThe galaxy NGC 1156 which is said to resemble a cherry blossom tree. Captured by the Hubble Telescope on July 22The sun rises over Earth as captured from the International Space Station on July 15The Namibian port town of Walvis is captured from 262 miles above on the International Space Station“Ironically, our payload may be the only surviving thing from that mission,” Nova Spivack, who helped get them there, told Wired, which first reported on the tardigrades' space exploration mission.Moon is significantly older than we thought, study findsMr Spivack founded the&nbspArch Mission Foundation, which is trying to leave copies of human knowledge around the world. He and his organisation loaded the Beresheet lander up with a library that could serve as a summary of life on Earth: 30 million pages of information, samples of human DNA, and the tardigrades.Tardigrades were first discovered in the 18th century, and have fascinated scientists ever since. They are tiny, measuring just half a milimetre long, and are found all around Earth.Much of the reason for the fascination is just how able they are to withstand extreme environments and survive. They have shown the ability to be exposed to very high and low temperatures, intense pressure, as well as being deprived of air, food and water, as well as already demonstrating that they can live after being put in outer space.They do that party by going into a very strange hibernation, where they can switch off a variety of biological processes and then restart them again when they wake back up. They could be doing that on the Moon, scientists warn, ready to be revived when conditions are right.As such, scientists don't think that the tardigrades will be thriving on the Moon. But they could be waiting there ready to be picked up and revived, they say, and could stay in that state for years.On other planets that could potentially be home to life, Nasa and other space agencies are very careful about contaminating the surface with life from the Earth. But the Moon is considered dead and so restrictions are much less – with Apollo astronauts leaving bacteria there in the fecal matter they dropped on the surface.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsBe inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Tesco  outlets were originally designed for a weekly shop but&nbspseven in 10 customers now use them as convenience stores, purchasing food to eat that day, the company said.To adapt to this change Tesco said it would implement faster and simpler ways of filling shelves, keeping less stock in store rooms and more on shelves. We must be ‘greener’ rather than ‘greyer’’Click to followIndy PoliticsA radical overhaul overhaul of planning rules that would make green space as vital as access to water or energy is being considered by London's mayor.Sadiq Khan has signalled he will support the scheme to make it easier for all residents of the capital to enjoy areas away from buildings and traffic if he secures a second term in City Hall.A fifth of London is more than a kilometre from areas of nature, despite the fact that green space accounts for nearly half of the city (47 per cent), according to a report by the Fabian Society, which will be published on Friday.It says that future developments should guarantee that every resident is no more than 1,000m away from a patch of land that is not covered in concrete or tarmac.The mayor of London has thrown his weight behind the initiative,which calls for housing&nbspestates with poor access to nature to be flagged for future enhancements in&nbsprecommendations outlined by wildlife activist David Lindo.Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 51Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Beer enthusiasts taste beer and ale during The Great British Beer Festival at Kensington Olympia in west London. That’s democracy... there&nbspare other views within the party but that’s our view.”Labour’s manifesto at the 2017 general election claimed independence in Scotland would “lead to turbocharged austerity for Scottish families”.The document added: “Labour opposes a second Scottish independence referendum. It is unwanted an unnecessary, and we we will campaign tirelessly to ensure Scotland remains part of the UK.”Speaking earlier this year on the issue of a second referendum for Scotland, Mr Leonard said a Labour government would “not agree to to a second independence referendum”.Majority of Scots back independence in shock poll after Johnson visitMr Leonard added if Labour won a general election the party would refuse to grant a “Section 30 order” giving Holyrood the power to hold a second vote on independence.“What we said in the manifesto at the 2017 election was that there is no case for, and we would not support, a second independence referendum.”Following Mr McDonnell’s remarks, a Scottish Labour spokesperson insisted the shadow chancellor was “clearly not advocating a second independence referendum”.&nbsp“He made clear the huge benefit a UK Labour government&nbspwill bring for the people of Scotland”.On Brexit, Mr McDonnell said Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn would “never” step down if other opposition parties demanded it to form a coalition of national unity.Government accused of playing ‘blame game’ over no-deal BrexitUK’s hopes of good post-Brexit trade deal with US branded ‘delusional’EU prepares for no-deal as PM has ‘no intention’ of renegotiatingNigel Farage cleared by Ofcom for saying Jon Snow ‘should be attacked’The shadow chancellor said:”It won’t happen. I think we’d form a minority government, seek to implement our manifesto and we’d expect the other opposition parties and other MPs to vote for those policies and if they don’t we’ll go back to the country.“If they want to vote against a real living wage, if they want to vote against £70bn&nbspworth of investment in Scottish infrastructure, if they want to vote against a green industrial revolution to tackle climate change then so be it, we’ll go back to the people and then let them explain to the people why they wouldn’t support those policies.”“We want to change the world, we’re not going be held back by other parties.”Mr McDonnell’s remarks echoed comments from the party’s senior frontbencher Rebecca Long-Bailey, who earlier told Channel 4 News that Labour “wouldn’t countenance” a government of national unity.“We think that we need to have a clear majority for a government in parliament, and that’s why we’re calling for a general election,” she said.&nbsp“What we don’t want is a national unity government that gives Boris some sort of get out of jail free card.”The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxThe latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. This is the slowest rise since the BRC started collecting records in 1995.&nbspIn July alone, sales ticked up 0.3 per cent from a year ago after falls in the previous two months.&nbsp“The UK may have had record temperatures in July, but retail sales were far from record-breaking at just 0.3 per cent growth,” said Paul Martin, UK head of retail at KPMG, which sponsors the survey.&nbspHe noted that online non-food sales, which have held up particularly well this year, increased by only 3.7 per cent last month – a “considerably” slower rise than in previous years.Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Australia's Nathan Lyon celebrates after taking the wicket of England's Joe Root during day five of the first Ashes test at Edgbaston. title: jeremy corbyn labour brexit prime minister
story: But with Boris Johnson elected as the new Tory leader, is this his time to make a leadership move  Heres what we know about Corbyn.He spent three decades as a backbencher before taking the top spot in the lefty party.Born in Chippenham, Wilts., on May , , Jeremy Corbyn is the youngest of three sons.After attending a private prep school and state grammar school, the politician briefly worked at a local newspaper and at the age of , he volunteered in Jamaica for two years.He then worked as a trade union organiser and was elected a councillor in Haringey, North London, aged .In  Corbyn, , was elected as Labour MP for Islington North - the constituency he has represented ever since.On his website, Corbyn says: “I remain every bit as determined to fight for a better society today, as I was then.As a backbench MP he was known as a radical who backed hard-left policies and voted against his own party more than  times.Following Labour’s defeat in the General Election in May , Corbyn announced he was standing as a candidate as party leader.He was seen as a rank outsider, but stunned Westminster by winning the party leadership in September.Corbyn has been married three times.His third we, Laura Alez, is an ex-banker who is  years younger than him.Corbyn orced from his second we, Chilean exile Claudia Bracchitta, in  after  years of marriage. They have three sons together.He was married to his first we, academic Jane Chapman, from  to .According to Spears, the Labour leader’s net worth is a staggering £million.Corbyn is suggesting that Labour WILL back a second referendum in his latest Brexit flip-flop.The leftie leader said there should be a public vote on any deal agreed by Parliament.His U-turn comes after Labour slipped to third place in the polls with Remainers abandoning the party in favour of pro-EU rivals.The party has previously said it would support a second referendum in order to stop No Deal or a bad Tory deal.But now Mr Corbyn has suggested hell back a so-called peoples vote on any deal at all.The Labour leader told the BBCs Andrew Marr Show: I want us to get a good deal and then have a decision of the public after that.If we can get that through Parliament, the proposals weve put, then I think it would be reasonable to have a public vote to decide on that in the future.The next general election is not due until  - although in todays topsy-turvy politics, no one would rule out an earlier ballot.Theresa May resigned on May  and now Boris Johnson has the top job after winning the Tory leadership contest.It is uncleara General Election will be called before the next one.The Labour party would have to win a large number of seats for him to become PM.The odds of him being the next person in number  are  , according to William Hill.Corbyn spent most of his -year career as an MP as an obscure backbencher.But in a remarkable turn of events the bearded throwback leftie was propelled from the political fringe to leading the UKs main opposition party.Ed Miliband, who lost the General Election against the odds in , decided to open up future leadership contests to the public for a £ fee.But instead of drawing in a wide spectrum of society, the opportunity to vote was seized by a hard left faction which later became known as Momentum.And so with their support the crumpled maverick won the votes.Corbyn’s low-fi style in contrast to other polished politicians also won him support from young people looking for a no-frills socialist leader.His leadership was then challenged in  after his lacklustre support for the Remain camp in the Brexit vote.After a no-confidence vote was supported by  Labour MPs to  against, a leadership battle began between Corbyn and Welsh MP Owen Smith.But after Momentum marshalled support for him, Corbyn actually increased his leadership from . per cent to . per cent.However, after just four years doing the job it was rumoured he was tired and fed up.Allies have reportedly claimed hell soon hand over to another MP.One Shadow Cabinet member told the Evening Standard: Corbyn is ready to step down. He wants to step down.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: ireland economy no deal brexit leo varadkar
story: His Government’s own warnings about a No Deal Brexit are even more chilling than its Central Bank’s last week.“Disruption to daily le”. A “permanent reduction in the size of the economy”.Dublin paying more to Brussels, while cutting spending at home. UK firms, free of EU red tape, gaining “a competitive advantage” over Irish rivals.Varadkar could have been a thoughtful mediator between us and the EU. Instead, on Brussels’ behalf, he still plays the hardman over his toxic “backstop”.Boris Johnson is calling their bluff. No one yet knowshe can force No Deal through on October  against the will of Remainer MPs and a rogue Speaker.ButBrussels is relying on them, or a mythical pro-EU Government getting elected, they are gambling with the security and jobs of millions of their citizens.Citizens who will not thank them on November  for calling it wrong.JOHN McDonnell has lost his mindhe thinks he of all people can accuse our new Chancellor of being unfit for office.Ex-banker Sajid Javid knows more about finance than every Labour MP combined.His opposite number McDonnell, meanwhile, is merely a sniggering thug who rooted for the IRA as they murdered our soldiers.Who revels in hard-left violence and “jokes” about lynching or murdering Tory women. Who as a Trotskyite councillor was sacked for trying to set an illegal budget, but now wants voters to trust him to run the Treasury.Masquerading as a statesman-in-waiting, McDonnell thinks he can pronounce on the Chancellor’s morality.The public are wise to him.HOME Secretary Priti Patel is right to demand answers on the Carl Beech case.It was already staggering that the failed Met chief Bernard Hogan-Howe swanned off to the Lords. And that three cops prominent in the Operation Midland scandal just quietly retired.We now know that Steve Rodhouse, who ran Midland and put its victims through hell with zero credible ­evidence, is living in clover with a ­promotion, a £,-a-year package and a pension pot nearing £million.Meanwhile Tom Watson MP, the malevolent conspiracy theorist, somehow remains Labour’s deputy leader despite his credibility lying in ruins. His career, and Rodhouse’s, should be over.Someone must pay for destroying the lives of innocent men by giving credence to a wicked paedophile fantasist.Ms Patel must ensure it is never swept under the carpet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ecigarette battery exploded golfing pro
story: Will Hawksworth, , was driving to work when he says the batteries exploded “like fireworks” – with the flames burning his chest and stomach through his clothes.The PGA professional, based at Wortley Golf Club, desperately leapt from the car as the battery’s flames consumed the vehicle on January  last year.Speaking to the Sun Online, Will recounted: “I was driving with my girlfriend in the passenger seat and she yelled ‘stop the car, stop the car, you’re on fire’.“It was like a firework had gone off in my pocket.“It burnt across all of my chest, all of my stomach through my clothes.Will, who had the battery in his gilets top pocket,  said he managed to pull himself free from the car on Redmires Road in Sheffield as the batteries fell into the vehicles centre console.The flames then ripped through his car, with fire crews having to be called in to extinguish the fire.He said: “I got out the car and my clothes were hanging off me.“They were all burnt – I had bits of clothes I was trying to peel off.“It was snowing at the time so I grabbed the cleanest snow I could find and tried to put myself out.”Will had only just bought the batteries the day before the fire, charging them and putting them back into their cardboard box.Electronic cigarettes are handheld vaporisers that use batteries to simulate smoking.But Will said he had now given up the devices - too traumatised after his horric injuries.He was unable to work for weeks after the fire, and still has scars across his chest.He said he now opted to smoke instead of using e-cigarettes as he was concerned over the safety of the electronics.Will said: They just arent safe.I wouldnt feel safe charging the batteries overnight when it has the capability of burning my house down.And the young man is now in the process of claiming compensation from ecigarette battery company Efest.He said: “People need to know about the dangers.”Efest has been contacted for comment.The companys website warns not to mix batteries and metal objects, advising users to store products in a cool, dry area.However, Will said the battery was the only thing in his pocket at the time of the fire.It comes after passengers were left in shock as an e-cigarette burst into flames in an overhead locker.And a man was left in a coma after using a cheap e-cigarette he bought off the street in the US.Last month, we reported that a teenager had suffered horric injuries after his e-cigarette exploded in his mouth and blew out his teeth.

title: great british bake off john whaite sister portugal found
story: Relieved John, , revealed this morning that sis Victoria Cunningham was tracked down just in time after a Good Samaritan recognised her in the Algarve.He also thanked well-wishers who helped spread the word of her disappearance - telling them they had saved a le today.It follows a desperate appeal to track her down that included celebs Amanda Holden and Alan Carr sharing pleas on social media.Victoria, who suffers from severe mental health issues, was said to be very distressed and was found JUST in time, her brother said.Arrangements are now being made to bring her home safely following her ordeal.The  Bake Off champ tweeted: I am delighted to say that Victoria has been found.She is alive, she is sober but she is very very distressed .He added: A stranger recognised her and took her into her house.Each and every one of you, who has tweeted, shared and commented, has saved a le today.And I cannot thank you enough - you are all angels.We are now going to focus on getting her home and back in good health in the privacy and protection of our family.My gratitude to each one of you is undying.Youve helped save a sister, a daughter and a mother - thank you.John also thanked celebrities like Dragons Den star Duncan Bannatyne, Britains Got Talen judge Amanda Holden, presenter Lisa Falukner and comedian Alan Carr for spreading the message.The Bake Off star added: I also must thank the media who have been so gentle and helpful in this matter.If you wish to continue to help, please research in depth PMDD.Spread the word and hopefully more lives will be saved.Victoria vanished after being denied entry on a Jet  flight on Saturday morning with her boyfriend because she had been drinking.Her partner left her at the airport to fly back to the UK with his children.Along with posting a number of pictures of her on Twitter, panicked John had written: Please retweet. My sister has gone missing from Faro Airport. We are all worried for her welfare...Her name is Victoria Cunningham. She has no passport with her. If you see her please tell her that her family just want her home safe and sound.While many women suffer mild symtoms of PMS, the symptoms of PMDD are much more severe.Experiencing PMDD can make it dficult to work, socialise and have healthy relationships.In some cases, it can also lead to suicidal thoughts.Symtoms include: mood swings feeling angry or upset, anxiety, dficulty concentrating, lack of energy and suicidal feelings.It can also lead to physical symtoms like headaches and sleep problems.Source: MindJohn said in a video message that his sister suffered from depression and had been diagnosed with premenstrual dysphoric disorderand could possibly pose a threat to herself.In the video message he thanked people for their support and said: “My sister has severe mental health issues.She has depression for which she is taking Citalopram and she has been diagnosed by a consultant specialist in the field of female hormonal health has having PMDD.Which is a disorder where she will go pretty much insane in the week before and during her period.The result of those diagnoses means she will sometimes go on binges of drink and drugs.During those she will sometimes show signs of self-harm and attempt suicide.She’s vulnerable and a risk to herself.”He added: The time line is as follows: Saturday August  at .am she was due to get a Jet  flight out of Faro back to the UK.Her boyfriend left her because she was too intoxicated to get on the flight.He came home with his children and left her on a bench at Faro Airport.She slept on the bench for a couple of days while the police kept an eye on her. She wasn’t in custody.Yesterday, August  she was due to get the pm flight, flight number , out of Faro back to the UK.For some reason she has thrown her passport down along with all of her belongings and left the airport.She tried to leave the airport without paying for a can of Coke, so we can infer she has no money at all.We don’t knowshe has a debit card. Her mobile is going to an English voicemail so I think it is back in England with the boyfriend.We don’t know where she is. My sister Jane Tasker and a family friend Chris Darwin are currently flying out there to try and find Victoria and bring her back.We just want her home. We love her dearly.Brit holidaymakers chipped in to help try and track down missing Victoria.Kris Doog said he saw her on Sunday in Faro.She sat and chatted to him and his pals at a bar outside the airport.Kris, of Long Bennington, Lincs, tweeted John saying: “I saw your sister at Faro on Sunday, probably around pm.“She sat with us for  minutes or so in a bar outside the airport. Please contact meI can help.”Andrea Noble, of Manchester, said: “I am staying about  mins from Faro though without money she will prob not get down here.“Will keep an eye out. Hope she is found safe  well. She obv has an amazing caring family.”John won the third series of the then-BBC hit show when he was  - and now works as a chef and TV presenter.He has also written a number of cookbooks.John has appeared on a number of TV shows including Lorraine, This Morning, Sunday Brunch and hosted ITVs daytime cookery show Chopping Block with Rosemary Shrager.If you are affected by any of the issues raised in this article, please call the Samaritans on   or   . Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: shipyard belfast harland and wolff titanic heyday 158 years
story: Harland and Wolff was founded in  and quickly became one of the worlds biggest shipbuilding yards - but an insolvency request could not spell the end for the firm.At its height, Harland and Wolff employed more than , people and was booming during Belfasts golden age of shipbuilding.The innovative shipbuilders were among the first to replace wooden upper decks with iron - revolutionising shipbuilding and making the vessels much stronger.They also made the ships flatter and squarer at the bottom - increasing the capacity.Edward James Harland and Hamberg-born Gustav Wolff founded the firm, which is best known for building the RMS Titanic,  years ago.In the early th century, it was the most prolic builder of ocean liners.During the Second World War, the company helped build up Northern Irelands shipping assets, producing  warships,  merchant ships and over  tanks.With works beginning in , the iconic ship was built at Harland and Wolffs shipyard in Belfast.It was the largest ship afloat at the time and had an estimated , passengers and crew on board.Tragically, the liner is known for hitting an iceberg just four days into its voyage to New York City.The Titanic was wrecked and sank in the Atlantic Ocean within just three hours of hitting the iceberg.It is thought that more than , people died during the shipwreck.These images capture the busting brilliance of the shipyard in its prime, when it dominated the world stage of shipbuilding.However, this week it has been revealed that the business will cease trading, putting  jobs at risk.An accountancy firm DBO has been appointed administrators to Harland and Wolff, which could end the iconic  year legacy of the company.Unions representing workers have called for the shipyard to be nationalised, arguing that it would be cheaper for the government to keep the shipyard open and running.However, officials have advised against government intervention leading to fears that the shipping company may be coming to its end.

title: queen reunited shetland pony
story: The -year-old - an avid horse fan - made sure to say hello to the Cruachan IV as she kicked off her summer holidays at Balmoral in Scotland.She didnt seem to be put off from their previous encounters, that saw the Shetland do a poo in front of her last year.And its not the first time the small pony had a memorable meeting with the Queen - two years ago trying to eat her flowers.But the Queen - noticeably without flowers - seemed eager to pat the pony this afternoon.In a baby blue outfit with matching hat, the monarch seemed relaxed for her trip up north for the summer months.And she has good reason to be in good spirits - staying in her favourite royal residence in Scotland.The Scottish castle has been in the Royal Family since  and boasts over , acres of land,  bedrooms and is estimated to be worth a cool £ million according to Business Insider.However, the breath-taking estate - situated in Royal Deeside, Aberdeenshire - holds more than just monetary value for the Royals as the sprawling countryside castle allows them privacy away from The Queens Buckingham Palace headquarters.In the recent documentary Our Queen at Ninety, Princess Eugenie said her grandmother is the most happy during her Balmoral visits as she occupies her time with walks, picnics and a lot of dogs.Whats more, Prince Philip has taken a keen interest in gardening and created a large vegetable garden which adjoins to the lavish gardens on the North side of the castle, the Royal Familys website reveals.And according to Balmorals official website, The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh take a close personal interest in running and improving the Estates and visit the castle at least once a year on their summer break.In more Royal Family news, The Queen has made an unusual effort to welcome Meghan Markle as she doesnt want her to feel alienated like Princess Diana, a royal commentator has claimed.And Meghan Markle should be a lady, not a hustler according to controversial Lady Colin Campbell during her Good Morning Britain appearance.

title: photos natural world earth nature pictures
story: Stunning photography from around the world reveals the wonder of Mother Earth from a cuddly koala having a nap in a tree to a trio of cheetahs tearing apart their latest kill.The pictures also capture the sheer beauty of the natural world in vivid detail with a series of scenic shots that include majestic mountains, colour rainbows and the power of a lightning storm.Some photos also contrast the vast scale of the natural world and our own place in the great scheme of things.One shot shows the huge scale of a waterfall in Indonesia compared to a person standing in front of it.Another sees a man standing alone in a forest in Spain, completely dwarfed by the sheer scale of the trees.

title: new global nuke arms race china russia us
story: Beijing said it will not stand idly byWashington goes ahead with the planned deployment this year - sparking fears of a new Cold War.This comes after the US withdrawal last week from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treatywhich it signed with the Soviet Union in .China’s director of the foreign ministrys Arms Control Department, Fu Cong said the move would have a direct negative impact on the global strategic stability as well as security in Europe and the Asia-Pacic region.Fu said China was particularly concerned about announced plans to develop and test a land-based intermediate-range missile in the Asia-Pacic sooner rather than later, in the words of one US official.China will not stand idly by and be forced to take countermeasures should the US deploy intermediate-range ground-based missiles this part of the world, Fu told reporters at a specially called briefing.He also advised other nations, particularly South Korea, Japan and Australia, to exercise prudence and not allow the US to deploy such weapons on their territory, saying that would not serve the national security interests of these countries.US Defence Secretary Mark Esper said in Asia over the weekend that he wanted to deploy mid-range conventional missiles in the Asia-Pacic within months.Australian officials said Monday that the locations for the bases were not yet known but their country would not be one of them.Fu also said China had no intention of joining nuclear weapons reduction talks with the US and Russia, pointing to the huge gap in the size of Chinas arsenal compared to those of the other two.China has an estimated  nuclear warheads deployed, compared to , for Russia and , for the US, according to the Federation of American Scientists.Russian President Vladimir Putin has called for urgent arms control talks to prevent a chaotic arms race following the treatys demise.He also said Monday that Russia would only deploy new intermediate-range missilesthe US does.China has already shown maximum restraint in developing its arsenal and stuck to its policy that it would not be the first to use a nuclear weapon in a conflict, Fu said.I dont think it is reasonable or even fair to expect China to participate in an arms reduction negotiation at this stage, Fu said.He added that China remained committed to multilateral efforts to reduce nuclear stockpiles, such as the UNs Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty, although it has yet to raty that agreement.Fu wouldnt elaborate on what countermeasures China was considering taking against the US, saying only that everything is on the table.”However he did say China has never and would never take part in a nuclear arms race.Nor would he say how China might retaliate against countries that hosted US land-based intermediate-range missiles.China has previously used economic means to retaliate against South Korea over its deployment of an American anti-missile defence system.Fu dismissed US arguments for leaving the treaty as pure pretext, saying Washington was merely looking for an excuse to develop new weapons.If Washington truly believes Russia is cheating on the treaty, as it says, than the way forward is to negotiate rather than withdraw, he said.Meanwhile, Washingtons argument that it is threatened by China because  percent or more of Chinese missiles fall into the intermediate-range category doesnt hold up, Fu says.He explains that those missiles would be unable to reach the continental United States.So the US would be the least to worrythat is the case, Fu said. That shows that all of this is nothing but a pretext.Defence analysts say Chinas large arsenal of land-based intermediate-range missiles are intended primarily to degrade Taiwans defences, target Guam and other key US bases in the region.Those are typied by the advanced DF- intermediate-range ballistic missile, capable of lofting both conventional and nuclear warheads, the latter to carry out a rapid retaliatory strike, and the DF-D, which is built to take out an aircraft carrier.And while China argues its nukes are small in number and purely for defensive purposes, major technological upgrades made by Beijing offer fresh arguments for why it should be included in future treaties, said Collin Koh, a regional security expert at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.The INF Treaty signed by Russia and the US in  expired Friday, with Washington saying it withdrew because of Moscow’s alleged violations of the pact.Russia denies breaching the terms.Some observers say the real reason was a perceived need to counter Chinas advances in missile technology and restore a balance in light of lingering questions over the effectiveness of anti-missile defence systems.The end of the INF Treaty comes amid rising doubts about whether the two countries will extend an agreement on long-range nuclear weapons scheduled to expire in  known as New START.Trump said he has been discussing a new agreement to reduce nuclear weapons with China and Russia.And I will tell you China was very, very excited about talking about it and so was Russia, Trump told reporters. So I think well have a deal at some point.Asked about Trumps comments, Fu said he didnt wish to contradict Trump, but repeated that China has no interest and, frankly, we dont think we are even in a position to participate in a trilateral negotiation aimed at a nuclear arms reduction.

title: meghan markle baby shower sneaked attention

telegraphing the change - says the report.However, the -year-old duchess was more concerned with the “literal optics” of her departure.Former actress Meghan was criticised for her lavish baby shower – which saw her rubbing shoulders with a host of celebrities, including Amal Clooney and Serena Williams.American TV anchor Gayle King and Meg’s best friend Jessica Mulroney also attended her whistle-stop tour of the Big Apple, which brought streets to a standstill.Fans and press lined up at barriers on Manhattans Upper East side the star-studded celebration in February - the full cost of which was not revealed by the state department.Delivery men were seen bringing large flower arrangements and decorations into The Mark - where she was staying in the £,-a-night penthouse suite.During the shower, Meghan left through an entrance around the side of the hotel to get in a State Department car and drive to the swanky ‘Polo Bar’ for dinner with pals.Trying to evade the cameras, she then tried to change the route to the restaurant that was just . miles away, but details of her trip were leaked.She was snapped going in and leaving the restaurant.The State Department files obtained by DailyMail also show Meghan changed restaurants at the last minute at lunch to a location where she couldnt be photographed.She had wanted to eat at Flora Bar, the Met museums lavish restaurant that has a large glass ceiling where the public - title: avoid publicity paul hollywood ask oscar winning judi dench
story: All the drama in his le — the latest being dumped by girlfriend Summer Monteys-Fullam after asking her to sign a laughably self-important “gagging order” — is entirely of his own making.Yet, in an Instagram post richer than triple chocolate mousse, he seemingly blames her for the media attention they attract. He also adds that: “I prefer a quiet le away from the day job.” And the band played Believe It If You Like.To recap: Paul is a master baker who caught a lucky break after being booked to appear on what became TV juggernaut The Great British Bake Off.Back then he was happily married to we Alex and, outside of an occasional media interview to plug the show, his home le never made the headlines.A bit of work and no play made Paul a dull boy when it came to clickbait. Then he had a fling with fellow TV chef Marcela Valladolid and all hell broke loose.Sex sells. It always has. So does scandal, and cheating on your we with a younger woman fits firmly into both categories.When the fling ended, the admirably forgiving Alex took Paul back, but the marriage faltered again and he took up with a -year-old barmaid with a fondness for miniskirts and crop tops.What’s not to love for the hundreds of “paparazzo”who make a living from how many times their photo gets viewed online It’s not rocket science, is it  Earlier this year I spotted Judi Dench out supermarket shopping.Yes, that Judi Dench. Dame of the British Empire. Oscar winner. Recipient of more awards than Mr Hollywood’s had hot buns.And favoured guest of chatshow host Graham Norton. But there she was, browsing the aisles and totally unbothered by anyone.Why  Well, firstly, she wasn’t wilfully drawing attention to herself by radiating self-importance. And secondly, while she’s paid to be dramatic on screen, her le outside of it is anything but.Meaning that, in everyday le, her showbiz currency — the aforementioned “clickbait” — is, depending on how you view such things, blissfully low.But , say, she decided to dump her conservationist partner David Mills for a young barman from her local pub, a photo of her low-key shopping trip would be front-page news. Simple really.Aside from the marvellous Ms Dench, there are oodles of A- listers who live non-famous lives, popping to the supermarket or going for a low-key dinner — for example, not The Ivy et al — with loved ones.Occasionally, they might be spotted and photographed, but they just keep their head down and ignore it, accepting that it’s a small price to pay for the myriad other benefits fame brings.NDAsare now commonly used by celebrities to ensure the silence of, say, a nanny who will be privy to what happens behind closed doors — and that’s perhaps understandable.But asking a lover to sign on the dotted line when you’ve already been together two years is saying, in so many words: “I don’t trust you, but I want to carry on sleeping with you.”Who can blame Summer for telling him to stick it where the sun don’t shine Famous US basketball coach and mentor, John Wooden , once said: “Talent is God given Be humble. Fame is man-given Be grateful. Conceit is self-given Be careful.”Wise words that Mr Hollywoodwould do well to heed.WHATEVER you think of Boris Johnson’s politics, it can’t be denied that he’s working his King Ashurbanipal socks offas our new PM.Hospitals, factories, flood-hit towns – you name it, he’s popping up there to put a smile on everyone’s face and reassure them that everything is under control.He’s the frontman while the rest of the bandare putting in the hours at the studio, hopefully producing the hits. Time will tell.But suffice to say, he’s already shaping up to be the UK’s cheerleader – a feat the more reserved and aloof Theresa May never quite managed.WHEN asked about children, Prince Harry replied that he and we Meghan might have “two, maximum”.Fair enough, I thought. After all, she’s  now and,she’s lucky, Mother Nature might let her conceive one more before her womb shuts shop.But no, it seems the royal couple’s decision is to do with population growth, despite experts saying that, globally, the birthrate is shrinking and the real issue is how long we’re all living.So unless he’s planning to pack Granny off to Dignitas, there’s not much he can do about it. But I digress.Regarding royal babies and, in particular, Harry and Meghan’s sensitivity around their firstborn’s privacy, perhaps they should copy his cousin Zara.She and husband Mike Tindall have two daughters, Mia, five, and Lena, one. There’s no showboating or churlishness, they just give their daughters as normal a le as possible via picnics, getting muddy, painting faces and rough and tumble – as seen in thisdelightful photo of mischievous Mia hitching a ride on Dad’s back.They occasionally get photographed, but clearly accept that it’s just one of those things and don’t let it bother them. A parenting template to be admired, whoever you are.THE author Alex Elle once said: “I am very cautious of people whose actions don’t match their words.”In which case, let’s hope she wasn’t invited to the recent Google Camp party in Sicily which,you’re one of the self-regarding A-listers in attendance, was a high-minded gathering to discuss the issue of climate change.Or to the rest of us – a boondoggle for entitled fools. How  to describe an event attended by  of some of the world’s richest people who arrived on eco-unfriendly private jets and luxury yachts Oh, the unacknowledged irony. Meanwhile, Leona Lewis and ious other celebrities, who advocate gun control, happily took a shilling or three to attend the Austria-based party of Gaston Glock – one of the world’s most famous gun makers.But back to Google Camp where – and I can’t quite believe I’m writing this – residents and hotel guests near the archaeological site of Selinunte were told by police to avoid looking out of their windows to protect the privacy of the invited A-listers dining al fresco.The same slebs, one assumes, who regularly virtue signal their moral credentials by advocating a world without borders, where everyone should be treated the same . . . yada yada. If hypocrisy was a movie, they’d all be winning Oscars.SCHOOLBOY Jay Hughes, , was talking to a friend outside a chicken shop in South London when a van pulled up and three men armed with machetes jumped out.His friend ran off and escaped but Jay stood in the shop doorway, where -year-old Nyron Jean-Baptiste stabbed him before boasting, “I got one”, and leaving the scene.Jean-Baptiste has now been jailed for “le” – whatever that means these days – while poor Jay’s distraught mother Cindy has been condemned to a letime of painful loss.Another devastated mother, Linda Burke-Monerville, spoke last month about sending her remaining children back to Nigeria for safety after losing three of her sons to violent crime in the UK.New Home Secretary Priti Patel said this week that she is resolutely focused on restoring law and order to our streets via extra police officers with greater powers.Talk is cheap – particularly when uttered by the majority of politicians. Action is what we need. And fast. Let’s hope she delivers before too many more young lives are snuffed out so brutally.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: whaley bridge residents return evacuation
story: Nearly all of the , people evacuated from the Derbyshire town had to face another night in shelter yesterday as engineers continue to work on a crumbling dam.But there are hopes that frustrated families will be able totoday after hero emergency services managed to reduce the water level by . metres on Tuesday.Derbyshire Police Deputy Chief Constable Rachel Swann told residents: I have got a meeting at pm tomorrow where I am expecting we will have good news.Inspections on Toddbrook Reservoir will continue work today to determineit is safe after days of heavy rain led its dam wall to nearly breach.Had it collapsed, a m-gallon wall of water would have engulfed the town of , people - potentially leading to scores of deaths and millions of pounds in damage.Police are expected to update residents at noon on Wednesday on the progress of the emergency repair and drainage work - which has prevented disaster.The Canal and River Trust said: “The water has been pumped out at a controlled rate and good progress is being made.”It said “all safety implications will be assessed” before a decision is made with police about what happens next.The reservoir is at  per cent of its holding capacity and authorities carried out a series of inspections yesterday.Only a small number of residents were allowed tolast night.John Lomas, who was permitted to go back on Tuesday, said: Its great to be back home.All the services guys have done an excellent job, Im very proud of them all.Another ing resident, Melissa Broxup, said the last few days had been a nightmare. An absolute nightmare.Ive not been able to go anywhere and Whaley is so quiet. Everyone in Whaley has been amazing. Its not easy.Asked what it was like to be one of the first to be let back in, she said: Its great. I can finally get some sleep. I just cant wait to get back in my flat.Im happy but on the other side Im gutted for those who cant come back.They joined  diehard locals in the Horwich End area who defied the evacuation order to stay - despite repeated pleas by cops for them to leave as there is still a “risk to le”.Dep Ch Cons Swann said: “We will repeatedly visit these people to remind them of the risks they are posing to themselves and emergency responders.“However there is no specic legislation under which we can force these people to leave.”The four determined families all live next to each other in Horwich End - and claim the slow trickle of people back into the area has proved they were right to stay.Malcolm Venton, , who stayed with partner Lorraine Ellis, , told MailOnline: Its vindicated us really, I felt that we were never in much danger and thats proven to be the case.A police woman this morning asked meI was was one of those refusing to move and I sad yes.She said that I was foolish and told me well be the ones who have to retrieve your bodies.We were only just within the evacuation zone andanything were to happen, I had a bag packed and the car parked outside to drive literally  yards or so up the hill to the safe area.It didnt seem worth all the hassle of moving out to a temporary shelter, particularly as one of our border collies, Meg, is sick at the moment and is limping and so hardly able to move.All that upheaval wouldnt have been fair on her.It is feared looters could hit the area with Derbyshire Police patrolling the ghost town with drones.The dam wall has been packed with  tonnes of aggregate which is being cemented into place to reinforce the spillway.Derbyshire Police said: “Once a level has been reached - and is able to be maintained - engineers will view the damage to the wall and a decision will be made regarding when it is safe for evacuated residents and businesses toto Whaley Bridge.”Fire chiefs have said specialist engineers have monitored the dam wall  hours a day with lasers and are reassured by their assessment.An RAF Chinook helicopter was used again yesterday to move sandbags in a bid to maximise the dam’s integrity.RAF Regional Liaison Officer for the North West, Wing Commander Gary Lane, said: The work we have done is just finding its feet.When you put a load of aggregate down it needs stamping in, weve not been able to flatten that because it has just been dropped.He said about  military personnel had been drafted in to help with the dam.Addressing what would happen once people are given the green light tohome, Ms Swann said all cordons would be lted and roads would go back to normal.In the meantime, she insisted that security measures were still in force in the area after reports of burglaries and prowlers.Ms Swann said: We can assure you that security of the area continues. We are using drones regularly to patrol the area.Members of the public at the meeting in Chapel High School, Chapel-en-le-Frith, were also told the dam would eventually have to be rebuilt.A spokesman for the Environment Agency said: We are very much in the emergency phase now and we are currently repairing and carrying out construction work.It is a long-term construction project, but we will not have started from scratch. It could take  months, two years, three years, who knows

title: family tui holiday ruined pool skin flake hair green
story: The Hoi family, who paid £, for the trip, said other problems at the Dimitra Beach Hotel in Greece included live electricity cables near beds, plumbing issues, and a damaged childrens play area.The London-based family flew from Gatwick on July  to spend two weeks on the island of Kos.TUI advertise the hotel where they were staying as having three pools, lots of activities for kids, and views overlooking the Aegean Sea.But on July , the day before the family ed, mum Jilly took to twitter to complain about a chemical imbalance in one of the pools.So TUI UK our holiday hell at FaulTUI Towers continues, she wrote.Quote from rep, You don’t issue standard health and safety checks on rooms or hotel, you rely on guest feedback.Little too late, won’t you say, and look at my children’s faces due to chemicals in the pool.Jilly, , was accompanied on the holiday by husband Thomas, also , and the couples three children.One picture she took shows her youngest, Sally, , with hair that appears to be stf and matted and has a clear green tint.Sally and her siblings, Marcus, , and Hugo, , were also left with dry skin and “blisters” on their faces.Photos also showed the grates around the pool appear to be filthy and covered in a substance that resembles green mould.Despite this, pool staff are seen scrubbing the sides and sweeping the water into the pool.Other pictures showed faulty lights, live electrical cables close to sleepers heads, and a playground that was rusted and damaged, leaving the children with blisters on their hands.Speaking today, Jilly said: “Our kids faces all blistered and scabbed and our daughters natural hair is green due to wrong use of chemicals in the pool.They tried to clean the dirty grates around the pool with a vinegar substance - it stank.This was after we had complained about the dirt.Once this happened to the kids faces and we could see the algae in pool we mainly swam in the sea.She added: “It’s a chemical imbalance in the pool - main thing is to keep them out until it heals and apply lots of bio oil.As long as it doesnt get infected.TUI had no answers to this. We were completely mis-sold this holiday to the extent it has affected our family so badly.You save all year for a  day family holiday and it turns to hell.An over-chlorinated pool can cause eye irritation and dry out hair and skin as a result of stripping the body of its natural oils.In extreme cases it can lead to a burning sensation and even nausea and vomiting.The combination of copper in the water and chlorine can result in hair taking on a greenish tinge.A TUI UK spokesperson told : We’re sorry to hear that the Høi family are unhappy with their experience in Kos.When the customers raised their issues in resort, our reps worked hard to resolve these directly.We offered to move them to an alternative room and have also offered them a gesture of goodwill as an apology.

title: labour torpedoed cross party coalition
story: A key ally of Jeremy Corbyn said the Opposition does not want a so-called “government of national unity” taking overBoris is toppled in a no-confidence vote next month.Rebecca Long-Bailey claimed the alternative regime made up of anti-No Deal MPs would give Boris a “get out of jail free card” and allow him to laterto Downing Street.Without Labour’s backing, it means the plan – seen as one of the few options left for Remainers to stop Britain leaving the EU on Hallowe’en – is doomed to fail.Miss Long-Bailey said last night: “We’re happy to collaborate on a cross-party basis, but we wouldn’t countenance a national government of unity, because we think that we need to have a clear majority for a government in Parliament, and that’s why we’re calling for a general election.“What we don’t want is a national unity government that gives Boris some sort of get out of jail free card, so as soon as Brexit’s been sorted out, he can sail back in without any problems at all, without a sufficient Parliamentary majority. That simply wouldn’t be right.”It will come as a blow to Tory rebels like Dominic Grieve, who have raised the prospect of a new cross-party government being formed in the aftermath of a no-confidence vote in Boris.He said earlier: “There’s nothing that the Prime Minister could do to prevent such an administration being formedthe majority of the House of Commons wanted it.”He earlier slammed Boris’ adviser Dominic Cummings, saying he showed a “characteristic arrogance with ignorance”.Where’s their majority  Who’ll be PM Corbyn, the secret Brexiteer loathed by all  Jo Swinson, of the Lib Dems, hated by Labour and many Tories Heidi Allen, the noted nitwit  Maybe the hopeless fop Keir Starmer  Would Corbyn stand aside for his vain underling  It’s all vanishingly unlikely.But imagine the election afterwards: the Tories, championing Leavers plus Remainers who value democracy, versus parties that ­conspired to defy the people.Best of luck with that, Remoaners.

title: prince harry two kid limit karren brady
story: While the other half have been too busy to criticise him because they’ve been lambasting his we Meghan for guest editing glossy mag Vogue, in which Harry’s “two kids max” declaration appeared when he was interviewed by primatologist , Jane Goodall.“What we need to remind everybody is: these are things that are happening now, Harry said about the climate crisis, adding that his views have shted since the birth of his son, Archie, in May.When Goodall cautioned him against having “too many” children, he said two would be their lot, to avoid being a burden on the planet.He said it was important to focus on taking care of the resources we have, rather than putting more pressure on them.Cue much outrage from critics accusing him of hypocrisy.The accusations are mainly that there are more efficient ways to save the planet than that — such as not flying by private jet.My first thought, though, was more along the lines of not counting chickens before they are hatched: when it comes to babies, you can’t plan how many you get to have.Also, sorry to be a realist, but any women over , as Meghan is, are referred to as a geriatric mothers. The reality is that maybe she only has time for one more.But, whether it’s for the environment or not, I don’t blame him for not wanting more than two children.I have two and the very idea of having had a third makes me feel weary. I’m just thinking of the sheer volume of childcare, laundry and meals required by each additional child.Sure, when it comes to considering whether two children is “enough”, Harry, left, and Meghan are dealing with dferent considerations to most of us.With hordes of staff, including nannies, cleaners and drivers, they could have multiple children and outsource ALL of the dficult stuffthey wanted to.But Harry and Meghan want to be hands-on parents — which can become exponentially harder with each child you have.Historically, there is pressure on Royal family members to have multiple kids.But, as with many other royal traditions, Harry and Meghan are planning to go their own way. And I commend them for that.I also think Harry should be applauded for speaking up about climate change, especially as this week the Met Office confirmed that the hottest years on record have occurred in the past ten years.So why shouldn’t he use his very public  to talk about things that matter to him and to try to inspire others But, as is often the case, this royal couple seem to be damnedthey do and damnedthey don’t.They’ve already learned the hard way — with their wedding their handling of Archie’s birth and their choice of residence — that you can’t please all the people all of the time.And that, in a way, is a liberation. Because all that is left is to please yourselves.  By ignoring pressures about how many children they “should” have, they are going to have as many as they damn well please.Although why they have to announce it is another question. Whatthey change their mind If they have two boys they might want to try for a girl. Apart from anything , you don’t know what your kids will ­contribute to the world.WhatThomas Edison’s parents had given up after two  . Or Louis Pasteur  .I admire and respect Harry and Meghan for going their own way, and for doing things the way that suits them.Andit affirms their choices to announce them to the world then all the better.In which case I guess it is anticipating losing more customers, too. I LOVE Kelly McGillis for how open and upfront she was recently about why Hollywood is no longer courting her.In an interview the -year-old actress was asked why she was not asked to co-star with Tom Cruise in the Top Gun sequel titled Maverick.“I’m old and I’m fat and I look age-appropriate for what my age is, and that is not what that whole scene is about,” said the star who played Charlie Blackwood, Maverick’s instructor, in the  hit film.“But . . . I’d much rather feel absolutely secure in my skin and who and what I am at my age as opposed to placing a value on all that other stuff.”How refreshing is that approach to le  Although she’s not old or fat at all – she just looks like most of us will look at .And what a relief it must be not to be squeezing herself into size zero dresses and having monthly Botox appointments.Still, McGillis is only five years older than Tom Cruise. And, of course, his career really is the gt that keeps on giving – mostly to the Mission: Impossible franchise.So it’s hard not to be annoyed by the take home from that. Namely that women can’t be in filmsthey look their age . . . whereas men can.Rather you than me, Heidi. But I guessyou marry someone in his s you take the rough with the smooth.They look super happy – and like they are having a lot of fun. Good luck to them both.I DON’T lose any sleep over it but, sometimes, especially when it’s bikini season, I find myself wondering what le might be likeyou happen to have been blessed with the kind of physique that Gigi Hadid has.She seems to have no apparent flaws whatsoever.And how would it feel not to have to spend most of your time on the beach arranging yourself in the “most flattering” way  THE story of Joe Plimmer, , an aspiring police officer who had his full driving licence for only  weeks when he smashed his car into a tree, killing his -year-old female passenger as he tried to keep up with a sports car, is so utterly tragic.Meredita Kelmelyte died when the Vauxhall Corsa they were in veered off the road and hit a tree at more than mph.It’s horric that she died and her family must be in pieces.Who knows how they feel about the fact that Plimmer has been sentenced to nine months in a young offenders’ institute.But you can guarantee that this young man’s le is already in tatters and will never be the same again. Jail will not bring back his passenger – is it really the right place for him to be ANYONE  punch the air and shout “Yes!” reading about the man who was caught urinating outside a train station then forced by police to clean up after himself with a mop and bucket British Transport Police refused the man travel and asked him to leave Worcester railway station on Sunday lunchtime.They also shared a picture of him cleaning up, describing his actions as “unacceptable” given that the station’s toilets were open.Sorry, but how many women do you ever see urinating in the streets – whether the toilets are open or not Also,this happened every time a man was caught urinating in the street, something tells me it would happen a lot less.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
